title: 114_hr3484
content: The Act titled "Los Angeles Homeless Veterans Leasing Act of 2016" authorizes certain leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may carry out leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus for purposes benefiting veterans and their families, including supportive housing, health promotion, education, and vocational training. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs may carry out leases at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus for purposes benefiting veterans and their families, including supportive housing, health promotion, education, vocational training, peer activities, legal assistance, volunteerism, family support services, transportation, and services in support of these purposes. Additionally, a lease of real property for up to 10 years to The Regents of the University of California, on behalf of its UCLA campus, is allowed if consistent with the master plan and for the provision of services to veterans. The lease at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus must focus on providing services to veterans, including additional support that benefits severely disabled, women, aging, or homeless veterans. The Regents must offer these services during the lease term, which may include medical, clinical, therapeutic, dietary, rehabilitative, legal, mental, spiritual, physical, recreational, and research activities. The lease at the Department of Veterans Affairs West Los Angeles Campus must focus on providing services to veterans, including additional support for severely disabled, women, aging, or homeless veterans. The Regents must offer medical, clinical, therapeutic, dietary, rehabilitative, legal, mental, spiritual, physical, recreational, research, and counseling services to veterans and their families. The Secretary is limited in carrying out land-sharing agreements that do not provide additional health-care resources to the Campus and benefit veterans and their families beyond generating revenue for the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Secretary may grant easements or rights-of-way on lands at the Campus to public transportation authorities for mass transit facilities. Revenues from leases at the Campus are exclusively for renovation and maintenance of the facilities. The Secretary may grant easements or rights-of-way on lands at the Campus to public transportation authorities for mass transit facilities, including fixed guideway facilities and transportation centers. Any improvements proposed under the easement or right-of-way shall be subject to appropriate terms and conditions. The easement or right-of-way shall be terminated upon abandonment or nonuse, with all rights reverting to the United States. The Secretary may not sell or convey fee simple title to any property at the Campus. Leases must align with the approved master plan. Noncompliance with laws may result in the Secretary taking action. The Secretary must ensure compliance with laws regarding leases and land use at the Campus before entering into any agreements. No lease can be entered into unless it complies with relevant federal laws. Additionally, a Community Veterans Engagement Board must be established within 180 days. The Secretary must establish a Community Veterans Engagement Board within 180 days to coordinate with the Department of Veterans Affairs, comprised of at least 50% veterans, to provide advice and recommendations for improving services for veterans and their families. The Board must provide community opportunities for collaboration and communication, focusing on local issues such as health care and benefits at the Campus. The Secretary must notify Congress and relevant representatives 45 days before entering into any lease or land-sharing agreement at the Campus. The Secretary must notify Congress and relevant representatives 45 days before entering into or renewing any lease or land-sharing agreement at the Campus. An annual report evaluating all leases and agreements must be submitted to the Committee on Veterans' Affairs, including revenue management and required records. Inspector general reports are required two and five years after the enactment of the Act. The Inspector General of the Department of Veterans Affairs must submit a report on all leases and land management at the Campus to the relevant committees and representatives every two and five years after the Act's enactment. The report should assess the Department's efforts to implement the master plan for the Campus. The General must consider the latest report submitted to Congress by the Secretary. This section does not limit the Secretary's authority to make other agreements related to the Campus. "Principally benefit veterans and their families" is defined as services exclusively for veterans and their families, excluding services that only benefit veterans. The text discusses the exclusion of services that only generate revenue for the Department of Veterans Affairs from benefiting veterans and their families. It also includes amendments related to the Los Angeles Homeless Veterans Leasing Act of 2016.
